Fig 1 Fig. 2 H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) profiles of the studied catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Raman spectra of the studied catalysts at different spots within the particle and particles. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Effect of support type at multiple temperatures on OCM performance for impregnated Mn-Na-W catalysts at W/F 0=4.42 gcat∙h∙molC −1 and the feed molar ratio CH4/O2=4.2/1. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Effect of the blending-shaping method for multiple βSiC-supported Mn-Na-W catalysts at T=800°C, W/F 0=5.67 gcat∙h∙molC −1 and the feed molar ratio CH4/O2=2.6/1 on C2 selectivity as a function of (a) CH4 and (b) O2 conversion and on COX selectivity as a function of (c) CH4 and (d) O2 conversion. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Performance comparison of mesoporous and β phase SiC support materials for impregnated Mn-Na-W catalysts and effect of the SiC crystal phase for Mn-Na-W spray-dried catalysts at T=800°C, W/F 0=4.61 gcat∙h∙molC −1 and feed molar ratio CH4/O2=2.5/1 expressed as C2 selectivity as a function of (a) CH4 and (b) O2 conversion and (c) as the C2H4/C2H6 ratio. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Evolution with time on stream for spray-dried catalysts of (a) CH4 and O2 conversion and (b) C2 selectivity and C2H4/C2H6 ratio and for IMP SiO2 and IMP βSiC of (c) CH4 and O2 conversion and (d) C2 selectivity and C2H4/C2H6 ratio at T=800°C, W/F 0=5.67 gcat∙h∙molC −1 and the feed molar ratio of CH4/O2=2.6/1. Fig 7 Fig. 8 High-resolution x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of spray-dried Mn-Na-W catalysts with different SiC crystal phases of (a) Mn 2p, (b) Na 1s, (c) W 4f, (d) Si 2p, (e) O 1s, and (f) C 1s. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image of spray-dried SiO2-βSiC catalyst at the (a) surface and (b) cross-sectional planes and energy dispersive x-ray (EDX) profiles along the highlighted lines of (c) C, (d) O, (e) Na, and (f) Mn. The SEM image of the spray-dried SiO2-α+βSiC catalyst at the (g) surface and (h) cross-sectional planes and the EDX profiles along the highlighted lines of (i) C, (j) O, (k) Na, and (l) Mn. Fig 9 Fig. 10 Evolution of the sample weight over temperature and its derivative over time (DTG) for both spray-dried Mn-Na-W uncalcined catalysts obtained from thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Fig 10 Fig. 11 Influence of temperature and the CH4/O2 ratio in the feed for spray-dried SiO2-α+βSiC on the C2 selectivity as a function of (a) CH4 conversion and (b) O2 conversion and (c) on the C2H4/C2H6 ratio. Reaction conditions: T=700°C, 750°C, and 800°C; W/F 0=4.50 gcat∙h∙molC −1 for all conditions. Supported Mn-Na-W on silica is a benchmark catalyst for oxidative coupling of methane due to its appropriate ethylene yields. Here we compare eight catalysts with the same active phase (Mn-Na-W) and variable support composition or particle blending-shaping method to evaluate the effect of the support. First, we explore the different preparation methods (impregnation, ball milling, and spray-drying), concluding that spray-drying leads to a promising selective catalyst. Then, we compare different SiC crystal phases (α+β and β), keeping the same composition and shaping method (spray-drying). The catalyst with α+βSiC crystal phase has significantly more activity than the β one in 30 h reaction runs. Finally, we assess the effect of process conditions to improve the yields (15 % at 800°C) of the most promising catalyst: spray-dried and with α+βSiC. The roles of the blending-shaping method and SiC crystal phase are explained by the induced differences in oxidation behavior and active phase distributions. OCM is much more environmentally attractive than steam cracking hydrocarbons, a very energy-intensive process (Spallina et al., 2017), promising to produce platform chemicals more sustainably. The development of highly selective C2 catalysts for OCM is fundamental because noncatalytic oxidation of CH4 to COX becomes more dominant at high temperatures (Liu et al., 2008, Kiani et al., 2019). Among the vast array of catalysts studied for OCM in the past decades, SiO2-supported Mn-Na-W has been the benchmark due to its unusual activity (20% to 40% CH4 conversion) and C2 selectivity (65% to 80%) (Li et al., 2018). Novel particle blending-shaping paths beyond the standard impregnation and mixed solution methods (Ki-June and Sang-Won, 1996), such as spray-drying or ball milling, have great potential for synthesizing OCM catalysts with enhanced performance, especially targeting large-scale methane valorization. In spray-drying, a slurry with precursors is atomized to form spherical droplets taken to a drying chamber by a carrier gas. The particle undergoes gradual shrinkage in the chamber, and solid particles are packed to create nanostructures (Gradon et al., 2020). Typically, spray-dried catalysts have a narrower and smaller particle-size distribution than those prepared by impregnation, with remarkable dispersion due to the enhanced surface-to-volume ratio during the drying and confinement of the precursor in the shrinking droplet (Santiago et al., 2011). Ball milling is another cost-effective and straightforward particle blending-shaping method that allows large-scale industrial productions with on-demand phase compositions (Rinaudo et al., 2020, Dindarsafa et al., 2017). In OCM, several authors (Arndt et al., 2011, Ivanova et al., 2018) have reported ball-milled catalysts activity comparable to those prepared by impregnation or precipitation. Especially remarkable is the work by Wang et al., (Wang et al., 2017), who synthesized a Ti-doped Mn-Na-W with promising activity at temperatures as low as 650°C. The Mn-Na-W catalysts supported on SiO2 provide a good selectivity-activity trade-off (Do et al., 2021). Nevertheless, the design and synthesis of novel catalysts that can make OCM industrially profitable are of paramount importance. Hence, the study of alternative support materials for Mn-Na-W is a fundamentally relevant aspect in the field (Gambo et al., 2018). In contrast to the conventional Mn-Na-W support materials, silicon carbide (SiC) presents high thermal conductivity and is a chemically inert (Kulkarni et al., 2022) and when highly exothermic reactions such as OCM are concerned, the inclusion of SiC in the catalyst support can eliminate or alleviate hotspots (Nguyen et al., 2007, Wang et al., 2008, Samarth et al., 1994). The outstanding thermal properties of the SiC support could also explain the extended lifetime (Yildiz et al., 2014), possibly due to the less intense catalyst surface temperature changes during the reactions. However, the effects of the textural properties of SiC in OCM catalysts lack consensus in the literature. For instance, activity improvements compared to the benchmark SiO2 catalyst with a porous SiC were reported by Serres et al. (2015), who attributed the improvements to the increased surface area. Nonetheless, during either calcination or reaction, the presence of Na causes a significant loss of support porosity and surface area, which induces the melting of the surface layer (passivation) that typically protects SiC against bulk oxidation. In that regard, Wang et al. (2017) ascribed the loss of OCM activity of porous SiC-supported catalysts to the lack of structural stability under reaction conditions. In our previous work (Lezcano et al., 2021), we demonstrated that SiC inclusion as a co-support with SiO2 improves stability while retaining high initial activity. We outlined that an inert catalytic material can significantly affect the direct methane conversion to C2 chemicals through oxidative coupling. The present study explores different catalyst blending-shaping methods and SiC crystal phases in SiO2-SiC support material for an OCM catalyst based on Mn-Na-W. Following that scope, SiC-supported catalysts with different crystal structures and particles shapes are synthesized using the standard wetness impregnation, spray-drying, and ball milling. The catalysts are thoroughly characterized using N2 physisorption, powder x-ray diffraction (PXRD), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Raman spectroscopy, and catalytic tests performed at multiple reaction conditions. First, we compare the blending-shaping methods and then the SiC crystal phase, providing additional characterization techniques –SEM-energy dispersive x-ray (EDX) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA)– to explain the different catalytic performances based on their oxidation tendencies and active phase distributions. The last section seeks the optimized process parameters for the most promising catalyst. 2 Methods 2.1 Preparation, blending, and shaping of the catalysts Following the wetness impregnation method, several Mn-Na-W catalysts were prepared. In the wetness impregnation method, the precursor salts of each metal in an aqueous form were impregnated into the support. The salts for catalyst preparation in the present study that correspond to Mn, Na, and W are manganese acetate tetrahydrate (Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O, Acros organics, 99%), sodium oxalate (Na2C2O4, Acros organics, 98%), and sodium tungstate dihydrate (Na2WO4·2H2O, Sigma, >99%), respectively. Salts were added to the support at 80°C with a target nominal composition of 2 wt.% of Mn, 5 wt.% of Na, and 3.1 wt.% of W. Water was subsequently removed by drying at 100°C for 6 h, and the dry samples were calcined in air at 800°C for 6 h with a ramp of 10°C min−1. The Mn, Na, and W were supported on fumed SiO2 (Sigma-Aldrich, 250 to 500 μm), a spray-dried colloidal SiO2 (Ludox TM-40, Sigma-Aldrich, 40 wt.% in water) and α+βSiC (US Research Nanomaterials, amorphous (10%), α (40%), and β (50%) phases, 99+%, 800 nm) blend, with in-house prepared mesoporous SiC and commercial porous βSiC (Alfa Aesar, β phase, 99%, 1 µm). The resulting catalysts were labeled IMP SiO2, IMP SiO2-α+βSiC, IMP meso-SiC, and IMP SiO2-βSiC. For catalysts with SiO2 and SiC in the support material, 70:30 wt./wt. was the nominal SiO2:SiC ratio. Mesoporous SiO2 (SBA-15) was first hydrothermally synthesized under acidic conditions using a gel composition of 1 tetraethyl orthosilicate: 0.017 Pluronic-P123: 9.60 HCl: 108 H2O to prepare the mesoporous SiC support, as described elsewhere (Krishna et al., 2018). After the heat treatment at 80°C for 24 h, the resulting product was filtered, washed, dried at 60°C for 6 h, and calcined at 550°C for 1 h in N2, followed by 5 h in the air. In the second step, the mesoporous SiC was synthesized by infiltrating sucrose into the mesochannels of the SBA-15 (Zhao et al., 2011). In a typical synthesis, 2.0 g of mesoporous SBA-15, 1.42 g of sucrose, 0.16 g of H2SO4, and 6.0 g of distilled water were mixed and dried at 100°C for 6 h and then at 160°C for another 6 h. The dried mixture was carbonized at 700°C in N2 to form SiO2/C composites, followed by heat treatment (mixed with Mg powder in SiO2: Mg molar ratio of 1:2) at 650°C for 6 h in Ar. The mesoporous SiC was obtained after etching the mixture with 10 wt.% HF (Sungyoung Chemical Limited) and 4 M of HNO3 for 5 h. A single Mn-Na-W catalyst supported on SiO2-βSiC (70:30 wt./wt.) was prepared by ball milling (BM SiO2-βSiC). First, a slurry with metallic precursor salts, colloidal SiO2, and βSiC was prepared, and distilled water (around 100% of the total weight of the slurry) was subsequently added. For the Mn-Na-W ball-milled catalyst, precursor salts and nominal loadings of the metals were the same as in the impregnated catalyst. After the blending (slurry preparation), zirconia beads (around 40% of the total weight of the slurry, 2 mm diameter) were added, which act as the grinding media for ball milling. The slurry was ball-milled for 5 h at 300 rpm in a high-energy planetary mill (Pulverisette, Fritsch). The obtained gel was dried at 100°C for 12 h, then calcination in the air at 800°C for 6 h. Two different Mn-Na-W catalysts varying the SiC type (i.e., crystal phase) in the support blend were prepared by spray-drying: SiO2-βSiC (SD SiO2-βSiC) and SiO2-α+βSiC (SD SiO2-α+βSiC). The spray-drying synthesis begins with the preparation of the slurry, like in the ball-milling synthesis. Slurries were formulated for the same target nominal composition of metals and SiO2/SiC ratio as the impregnated catalysts. After adding distilled water, the resulting mixture was ball-milled at 250 rpm for 30 min. The slurry was spray-dried (Buchi B-290 advanced mini spray-dryer) at a flow rate of 10 mL·min−1 with compressed air (0.75 m3·h−1) acting as carrier gas through a two-fold nozzle (aperture = 2.2 mm). Operating conditions for the setup were previously optimized (Shoinkhorova et al., 2019). After spraying, droplets were dried in the drying chamber at 200°C. Finally, spray-dried catalysts were calcined at 800°C in air for 6 h. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts In a Micromeritics ASAP 2040, N2 physisorption (-196°C) was performed with a priori sample, degassing for 10 h at 250°C. The SBET was computed using the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) equation from the resulting isotherms. The PXRD of the catalyst samples for crystallographic phase identification was executed in a Bruker D8 advanced diffractometer equipped with a Bragg–Brentano geometry fitted with a copper tube operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Data were acquired over a 2θ range of 10° to 80° with a step size of 0.1°, a scan speed of 0.5 s per step, and phase identification with the PDF-4+ (2021) library. The crystallite size was determined using the Debye–Scherrer equation. The H2-TPR tests were performed using an Altamira AMI-200ip, with prior sample pretreatment in Ar at 200°C for 20 min to remove the adsorbed species. The H2-TPR tests were conducted in a 10% H2/Ar mixture with a total flow of 50 mL·min−1 and a heating rate of 5°C min−1. Elemental analysis was performed using ICP-OES (Varian, Inc./Agilent Model 7200-ES). For microwave digestion, approximately 10 mg of catalyst was taken in a mixture of 1 mL of HCl, 3 mL of HNO3, and 1 mL of HF and subjected to a microwave-assisted heating program with a 15-min ramp time and 30-min hold time at 1000 W and 220°C. High-resolution XPS analyses were performed in a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer. Equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα x-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV) that operates at 150 W and a multichannel plate and delay line detector under a vacuum of 1∼10−9 mbar, spectra were collected at energies of 160 and 20 eV, respectively. All samples were loaded in floating mode to avoid differential charging before charge neutralization. Reported binding energies were referenced to the C 1s peak of the (C-C, C-H) bond, set at 285.0 eV. CasaXPS software was used for processing the spectra. The SEM imaging and EDX mapping was performed with an FEI TENEO VS microscope. The secondary electron signal was recorded for particle topography at 5 kV acceleration voltage and 10 mm working distance. A 20 kV acceleration voltage and 10 mm working distance was used for EDX analysis. The x-ray signal was recorded with an EDAX detector (Ametek). Particles were mounted on the aluminum stub using adhesive carbon tape and sputter-coated with 3 nm iridium to avoid sample charging during imaging. For the particle cross-section analysis, the particles were embedded in epoxy resin (EMbed 812, EM Sciences) and cured overnight at 65°C. Thin slices of about 500 nm thick were cut with a UC6 ultramicrotome (Leica) and deposited on carbon tape. A Renishaw Via Reflex confocal spectrometer with 473 nm laser excitation was used for surface and mapping Raman spectra collection. Mapping spectra were collected from the same catalyst sample used for SEM mapping. The sample was irradiated with a 25-mW laser for 1 s for every 30 accumulations. Thermal analysis was conducted using a gas controller GC 200 model TGA (Mettler Toledo) device for thermogravimetric measurements. About 10 mg of the as-synthesized sample were placed in an Al2O3 crucible and heated up from 30°C to 850°C with a temperature of 10°C·min−1 in a 30 mL·min−1 zero air flow. An empty crucible was used as reference material. 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic tests were performed in a high-throughput 16-fold parallel reactor (Flowrence, Avantium). Each reactor is built with quartz, 2 mm inner diameter and 30 mm length, placed inside a furnace. Reactors consist of a fixed-catalytic bed (around 50 mg, with particle sizes in the range of 150 to 300 μm) placed above a bed of coarse SiC (100 mm long), ensuring the catalyst bed lies within the isothermal zone of the reactor, with the gases flowing downward. One reactor was always left empty as a blank. The target space-time range was 4.42 to 5.67 gcat·h·molC −1 at 650°C to 800°C and atmospheric pressure. The molar composition of the feed was CH4:O2 2.5–4.23:1. Products were analyzed in an Agilent 7890B GC equipped with two sample loops with a TCD and an FID as detectors and He as the internal standard. In a typical analysis, products are injected after flushing the loops for 15 min. In the first sample loop, He, H2, CH4, and CO were separated in an MS5A column with two Haysep precolumns. Gases with retention times higher than CO2 were backflushed, and CO2 was separated from the permanent gases in another Haysep column before entering the MS5A column. The second sample loop consists of an Innowax precolumn and a Gaspro column, where up to C8 paraffins and olefins are separated. Conversion (Xi), selectivity (Si), and yield (Yi) of individual or lumped species i are defined as follows: (1) X i ( % ) = F i , 0 − F i F i , 0 · 100 (2) S i ( % ) = n C , i F i ∑ i = 1 N Prods . n C , i F i · 100 (3) Y i ( % ) = X C H 4 · S i 100 3 Results 3.1 Characterization The BET surface areas reported in Table 1 are mostly smaller than 10 m2·g−1. Although no strong connection exists between the observed surface area and SiC source or blending-shaping method, higher values were observed for the spray-dried compared to the analogous ball-milled or impregnated catalysts. Such an observation could be explained by the better dispersion of spray-drying when loading metals, especially compared to impregnation. Furthermore, catalysts prepared with βSiC in the support material exhibited slightly higher surface areas than those prepared with α+β phase SiC, in line with the literature (Kim et al., 2019), due to the superior surface area of the β phase SiC stemming from its higher intrinsic porosity. The literature has widely reported the generalized loss of surface area for OCM catalysts (Yildiz et al., 2016, Ismagilov et al., 2016) and explains the phase transition of the amorphous SiO2 to α-cristobalite during calcination. The presence of α-cristobalite and many more phases was corroborated through PXRD for most of the studied catalysts. Among the catalysts, only the diffractogram of BM SiO2-βSiC (Fig. 1 (a)) did not display the characteristic 21.7° peak of α-cristobalite. The Mn and Na were predominantly in the form of Mn3O4 and Na2WO4. Fig. 1(b) presents the differences between the crystal structure of the α+β phase SiC and β phase SiC bare uncalcined support ingredients, the former exhibiting characteristic peaks of both α (33.9° and 38.1°) and β (35.6° and 41.4°) phases. In contrast, the latter confirms the presence of only the β phase. Furthermore, SiC crystal phases are detected in the catalysts after calcination, both in the samples synthesized with the two types (i.e., IMP SiO2-α+βSiC and SD SiO2-α+βSiC) and the ones with only βSiC. Such observations contrast the results presented by Kim et al. (2019), who observed the bulk transition of a β phase SiC support material into α‑cristobalite. They also detected both α phase SiC and α-cristobalite peaks in the PXRD spectrum of support material with α phase SiC, which they attributed to only a surface transition to α-cristobalite, an observation valid in the α+β phase SiC catalysts in Fig. 1. In fact, for IMP βSiC, in which only βSiC is a potential source of SiO2 during calcination, both α-cristobalite and βSiC phases are observed, hinting that the latter's transition mentioned before took place only partially. The H2-TPR results presented in Fig. 2 clarify the role of spray-drying of Mn-Na-W catalysts compared to other synthesis procedures. The reduction of bulk Mn occurs in the range of 130°C to 500°C. However, the presence of Na and W positively and negatively shift the reduction temperatures, respectively, as observed by Ismagilov et al., Hence, the peaks observed only for spray-dried catalysts in Fig. 2(b) at 404°C and 435°C (and their corresponding shoulders at 488°C and 510°C) for SD SiO2-α+βSiC and SD SiO2-βSiC, respectively, are assigned to the reduction of the bulk Mn. The reduction of W over SiO2 support material is typically identified using a low-temperature peak around 400°C and a high-temperature peak around 700°C to 800°C (Hong-Shan et al., 2001). As a result, the high-temperature peaks identified in IMP SiO2 (Fig. 2(a)), SD SiO2-α+βSiC, and SD SiO2-βSiC could be linked to reducing W species. Higher temperature peaks are commonly related to the weaker W-support and W-Na interactions (Hong-Shan et al., 2001) and even to an enhanced dispersion of the WOX species (De Lucas et al., 1998). The presence of Mn, Na, and W together can make the temperature of W species decrease below even 700°C, meaning that the corresponding peaks in Fig. 2(a) of the BM SiO2-βSiC and IMP βSiC catalysts could be due to the reduction of mixed Mn-W or W species (Ismagilov et al., 2016). Likewise, the 588°C peak of IMP SiO2-α+βSiC reveals much weaker metal-support interactions than SD SiO2-α+βSiC. Fig. 3 presents the Raman spectroscopy results at room temperature. Raman spectroscopy of Mn-Na-W catalysts, especially those with SiO2 and SiC-based support, can provide information about the surface phases. The presence of cristobalite in all catalysts is confirmed in Fig. 3 through the characteristic peak around 780 cm−1 or peaks around 442 and 220 cm−1 (in the case of IMP SiO2) (Ji et al., 2002, Nguyen et al., 2021, Hou et al., 2006, Chua et al., 2008). The fact that IMP βSiC also shows the 780 cm−1 cristobalite peak indicates surface oxidation of βSiC to SiO2, which is in the form of cristobalite. The 780 cm−1 peak in IMP βSiC was assigned to cristobalite and not to βSiC due to the little Raman activity of the latter, as shown in Fig. 3 (b). Such observation is indicative of the relative ease with which surface βSiC can oxidize compared to its α phase SiC counterpart, whose characteristic Raman band peaks at 160 and 960 cm−1 are intact after calcination in the case of IMP SiO2-α+βSiC and SD SiO2-α+βSiC. Such observations align with the PXRD results in Fig. 1, hinting that βSiC oxidation can occur at any location besides the surface. In the case of BM SiO2-βSiC, the peak could also be mainly assigned to βSiC, provided that poor Na distribution leads to a deficient amorphous SiO2 transition. Regarding metallic phase identification, surface Na2WO4 (around 930 and 310 cm−1) (Ji et al., 2002, Werny et al., 2020) was identified for both spray-dried catalysts. However, the 960 cm−1 peak of αSiC phase is suspected of overlapping with the 930 cm−1 peak of Na2WO4 in the SD SiO2-α+βSiC sample. As a result, Na2WO4 was not detected in IMP SiO2-α+βSiC either. Furthermore, high Na loadings decrease tetrahedral WO4 bands from Na2WO4 at 930 cm−1. Other works (Nguyen et al., 2021) did not identify Na2WO4 when supported onto αSiC. Remark that although peaks of Na2WO4 have been identified under room temperature, several in-situ studies have reported that Na2WO4 is present as a molten salt beyond 700°C. This alters the active phase interactions at reaction conditions which will be further influenced by the SiC crystal phase, as seen through the reported in situ characterization in this work (Werny et al., 2020, Sourav et al., 2021, Si et al., 2022). BM SiO2-βSiC displas ays no other Raman band besides cristobalite, probably due to the migration of Na2WO4 to the bulk (in PXRD, Fig. 1). The presence of Mn on the surface of SD SiO2-α+βSiC was confirmed through the characteristic peak of MnWO4 at 886 cm−1 through the vibration of its octahedral WO6 (Ji et al., 2002). The presence and absence of specific Mn, W, and Na species from catalyst to catalyst indicate the role of the SiC crystal phase and synthesis procedure. 3.2 Effect of temperature and type of support The effects of the support type at multiple temperatures (650°C to 800°C) on OCM performance are displayed in Fig. 4 . The benchmark SiO2-supported Mn-Na-W catalyst prepared by impregnation (IMP SiO2) exhibits a significant increase in CH4 conversion and C2 selectivity with temperature. The C2 selectivity substantially increased from 3.9±0.4% to 43.7±2.9% when temperatures rose from 650°C to 700°C. Beyond 700°C, sharp CH4 conversion increases were observed, reaching 33.1±0.8% at the highest temperature. The Mn-Na-W impregnated into mesoporous SiC (IMP mesoSiC) proved to be an inferior catalyst regarding OCM activity and C2 selectivity compared to IMP SiO2. The observed trend of CH4 conversion followed an exponential behavior that reached 21.4±0.4% at 800°C, and the highest C2 selectivity (51.6±1.6%) also corresponded to 800°C. In Fig. 4, at all temperatures except 650°C, the performance metrics were more limited for the catalyst exclusively supported on mesoSiC compared to IMP-SiO2, highlighting that the mesoporous SiC prepared in this work alone is not a suitable support material, probably due to structural collapse during either calcination or reaction (inferred from the N2 physisorption isotherm change in Fig. S1, with surface area decreasing from 151 m2·g−1 to 2.91 m2·g−1). Mesoporous SiC, however, could be an interesting support ingredient and could yield a more positive outcome when calcined under less aggressive conditions (e.g., N2). When Mn-Na-W was impregnated on a spray-dried mixture of SiO2 and α+β phase SiC (IMP SiO2-α+βSiC), experimental observations indicated that at all studied temperatures, CH4 conversion was lower compared to the SiO2-supported analog. For instance, at 750°C, CH4 conversion and C2 selectivity reached 2.3±0.1% and 50.6±6.8% respectively, compared to 13.2±0.6% and 64.5±2.2% of IMP SiO2. Such differences could be attributed to weaker metal-support interactions in line with the H2-TPR results and emphasize that a two-stage spray-drying assembly is inadequate for synthesizing an Mn-Na-W catalyst for OCM. Nonetheless, the required lower temperatures (>650°C) to reach remarkable C2 selectivity compared to the other catalysts (>700°C) highlight the potential role of SiC as a support component, probably due to the enhanced thermal conductivity the latter endows to the catalytic particle. 3.3 Effect of blending-shaping method Fig. 5 compares the OCM performance in conversion and selectivity between the benchmark IMP SiO2 and various βSiC-containing support materials prepared by ball milling, spray-drying, and impregnation. The variability in the observed CH4 conversion (Fig. 5(a and c)) indicates the influence of the blending-shaping method, with only the IMP βSiC impregnated catalyst reaching values (23.8±0.5%) close to those obtained for the reference IMP SiO2 (26.3±1.4%). The catalysts prepared by ball milling (BM SiO2-βSiC) and spray-drying (SD SiO2-βSiC), whose support material contains both SiO2 and βSiC, exhibit the lowest CH4 conversion, with 17.0±0.7% and 11.2±1.5%, respectively. The similar O2 conversion of the ball-milled catalyst compared with other catalysts with OCM activity like IMP βSiC is evidence of the methane-to-secondary-product oxidation that the former catalyst promotes. Such an observation is corroborated in Fig. 5(a and b), which reveals that C2 selectivity with the BM SiO2-βSiC (23.2±0.7%) is far lower than the benchmark IMP SiO2 (53.5±3.1%) or IMP βSiC (54.7±1.4%), related to the lack of cristobalite after calcination, as confirmed through room temperature PXRD and Raman spectroscopy. The spray-dried catalyst with βSiC in the support material, despite its reduced activity, presents a remarkable C2 selectivity (61.1±0.3%), accounting for the highest of all catalysts in Fig. 5. The enhanced C2 selectivity could be attributed to surface Na2WO4 in the spray-dried catalyst coupled with higher reduction temperatures than IMP βSiC or IMP SiO2. The C3 selectivity in all cases was negligible (<1%); therefore, it was disregarded as a differentiating metric for catalyst performance in this work. 3.4 Effect of SiC variation To better understand the role of the SiC crystal phase, Fig. 6 compares the performance of catalysts supported on mesoporous and β phase SiC support materials prepared by impregnation. The catalyst with the mesoporous SiC support presents a lower C2 selectivity (50.7±0.5%) than the catalyst supported onto β phase SiC (68.2±0.3%), as well as lower CH4 conversion (14.5±1.5% and 23.0±0.8%, respectively). The pore collapse and subsequent loss of mesoporosity could explain the moderate performance of the mesoSiC. Figs. 5 and 6 reveal that IMP βSiC and SD SiO2-α+βSiC catalysts have the highest C2 yield among the catalysts tested. Fig. 6 addresses the potential of spray-drying Mn-Na-W onto SiC-containing support material, and the effects of the SiC crystal phase variation in spray-dried catalysts are presented. The catalyst supported onto SiO2-α+βSiC performed reasonably better than its more porous analog (SD SiO2-βSiC), particularly for CH4 conversion, as depicted in Fig. 6(a), with 21.2±1.2% compared to 15.9±1.5%, respectively. C2 yields of SD SiO2-α+βSiC are also at par with those of IMP βSiC. The differences in CH4 conversion reported for SD SiO2-βSiC in Figs. 5 and 6 are attributed to the space-time variation (5.67 and 4.61 gcat·h·molC −1, respectively) in each reaction condition. The proportionality between CH4 and O2 conversion is consistent with the C2 selectivity values in Fig. 6(a and b) that are similar for both catalysts. SD SiO2-α+βSiC exhibited a higher C2H4/C2H6 ratio, 1.47±0.01, compared to 1.20±0.02 of SD SiO2-βSiC. The role of the SiC crystal phase of the spray-dried catalysts is further highlighted in Fig. 7 , where the dynamic behavior of the reaction is studied. Fig. 7(a) reveals that the activity of spray-dried catalysts does not decrease throughout 30 h of reaction. This finding highlights that spray-drying of combined SiO2-SiC support materials is an efficient technique for synthesizing stable OCM catalysts as opposed to the most promising catalysts prepared by impregnation (i.e., IMP SiO2 and IMP βSiC) for which deactivation has been observed (Fig. 7(c)) and often reported in the literature. Furthermore, such catalysts undergo a C2 selectivity increase when deactivating because of a higher oxygen conversion drop than methane over time on stream. The other less promising impregnated catalysts do not undergo deactivation (Fig. S2), thus highlighting that the inclusion of SiC as a support ingredient through spray-drying endows both activity and selectivity, besides stability. The enhanced stability of SiO2-SiC-supported spray-dried catalysts could be linked to the higher reduction temperatures of the metals that comprise the active phases compared to the purely SiO2 or SiC-supported catalysts, as shown in Fig. 3. Nonetheless, the spray-dried catalysts appear to be somewhat different, given that the observed residual CH4 conversion after 30 h of SD SiO2-α+βSiC is 92% (from 27.4% to 25.5%), whereas CH4 conversion of SD SiO2-βSiC increases from 9.7% to 15.8% over time on stream, α+β phase SiC endowing higher OCM activity than β phase SiC alone. The increase in CH4 conversion followed by a steady evolution for SD SiO2-βSiC is typically attributed to a stabilization period that some catalysts occasionally undergo, as reported elsewhere (Chukeaw et al., 2019). The evolution of O2 conversion follows a trend like the CH4 conversion for both catalysts. For SD SiO2-α+βSiC, the initial decrease in O2 conversion (from 65.4% to 54.9% after 3 h) directly influences the evolution of C2 selectivity (Fig. 7(b)). The similar CH4 and O2 conversion behavior explains the very steady C2 selectivity of SD SiO2-βSiC, stabilized at around 60%, higher than that of α+β phase SiC. However, the C2H4/C2H6 ratios are lower in the former case. Thus, Fig. 7 proves that stable and more active, yet less C2 selective, catalysts can be obtained compared to β phase SiC when formulating the support for spray-drying Mn-Na-W with α+β phase SiC. To elucidate the role of the SiC crystal phase on spray-dried Mn-Na-W catalysts that led to different behaviors in Fig. 7, high-resolution XPS spectra of SD SiO2-α+βSiC and SD SiO2-βSiC and their relative derived surface compositions are presented in Fig. 8 and Table 2 , respectively. Although the type of SiC crystal phase seems not to influence the relative surface elemental composition, the overall elemental composition obtained using ICP-OES (also in Table 2) has a significant decrease in the elemental concentrations of Mn, Na, and W in the SD SiO2-βSiC, with particular attention to Na, whose actual loading is 1.55 wt.% lower than in the SD SiO2-α+βSiC. The elemental composition of the metals of the latter catalyst is relatively close to the target composition. The overall lower total loading in the SD SiO2-βSiC is attributed to its higher porosity that collapses during calcination in the presence of Na. Wang et al., (nullQ) reported that β phase SiC-supported Mn-Na-W catalysts lose their porous structure when calcined in the air instead of when calcined in an N2 environment. The acute loss of Na in SiO2-βSiC hinders the bulk transition of SiO2 to cristobalite, whose characteristic peak in the PXRD pattern was significantly less prominent (relative to their corresponding SiC peaks) than that of SiO2-α+βSiC. This feature was also observed in the case of IMP βSiC and IMP SiO2-α+βSiC in Fig. 1. From the XPS spectra of Mn 2p, Na 1s, and W 4f (Fig. 8 (a-c)), the similarity between the chemical states of Mn, Na, and W of both catalysts can be inferred in line with the analysis of the relative surface composition. The slightly shifted spectra of Na 1s and Si 2p for SD SiO2-βSiC could be attributed to the differences in dispersion and morphology. The broadness of the characteristic Mn3+ peak at 642 eV in both catalysts is indicative of the multiplicity of its oxidation states (Strohmeier and Hercules, 1984, Bayer et al., 2007). The presence of Na+, Si4+, and W6+ species could be confirmed by identifying their characteristic peaks at 1071.4, 103.3, and 35.6 eV, respectively, which could be related to the presence of Na2WO4 in the surface (Wagner, 1975, Moulzolf et al., 2001, Ho et al., 1987, Meškinis et al., 2020). However, the phases identified through Raman spectroscopy imply that identifying Na+, W6+, and Mn3+ using XPS, although confirming the existence of Na2WO4, is not entirely conclusive of the presence of Mn on the surface in the case of SD SiO2-βSiC. The C 1s spectra from Fig. 8(e) present three distinct peaks at 284.5, 285.9, and 287.9 eV due to C-C (graphite), C-O, and O=C-O species, respectively, in line with the observations from PXRD (Wang et al., 2017). The O 1s spectra of both catalysts (Fig. 3(f)) exhibit two peaks at 530.3 and 532 eV due to M=O (primarily due to SiO2) and M–O (e.g., adsorbed H2O or surface OH) species in the catalysts (Kim et al., 2021, Yang et al., 2015). The C 1s and O 1s are similar for both catalysts. In addition, the absence of a C 1s peak at around 282.5 eV and a Si 2p peak at about 100 eV suggests that the surfaces of both catalysts are primarily covered by a SiO2 layer, as confirmed by the O 1s spectra, with a modest presence or nonexistence of SiC (Wang et al., 2017). To further differentiate the differences between the activities of SD SiO2-βSiC and SD SiO2-α+βSiC catalysts, topographic SEM images are displayed in Fig. 9 (a-b and g-h). Fig. 9(a and g) portrays the surface of the particle of both catalysts and proves that, through spray-drying, particles with controlled spherical and homogeneous morphology can be synthesized in a continuous and reproducible mode, regardless of the type of SiC employed. However, the particle cross-sections in Fig. 9(b and h) corresponding to SD SiO2-βSiC and SD SiO2-α+βSiC, respectively, reveal significant morphological discrepancies from case to case, with the former displaying collapsed pores resulting in large cavities. The middle region in Fig. 9(b) corresponds to the near-surface of the particle due to the imperfect cutting of the cross-section. The EDX profiles of the lines in the SEM images in the relative intensity are depicted in Fig. 9(c-f and i-l) for SD SiO2-βSiC and SD SiO2-α+βSiC, respectively. Relative intensity was defined as the normalization of the spectra of a given element and sample concerning the maximum intensity for the same element and sample. Fig. 9(c) indicates that for SD SiO2-βSiC, the presence of carbon (SiC being the only C source) at the surface and cross-section is limited. In contrast, the presence of oxygen (Fig. 9(d)) is relatively constant (excluding the porous regions the profile line crosses). This result indicates the larger proclivity of β phase SiC to partially oxidize during calcination and form SiO2 in any of its phases compared to its counterpart. Such observation supports the conclusions drawn from PXRD and aligns with the SiO2-covered surface from XPS. Carbon surface and cross-section EDX profiles of SD SiO2-α+βSiC (Fig. 9(i)) reveal the scarcity of SiC on the surface and a cross-section where SiC is abundant. This distribution of SiC selectively being present at the center of the particle could be the reason for the imperfect cut shown in Fig. 9 (h) arising from the hardness of SiC in comparison to SiO2. Oxygen EDX profiles indicate that the core of the SD SiO2-α+βSiC particle (blue line) is leaner in oxygen than the surface (black line) or near the surface (red line). Furthermore, the maximum of the cross-sectional profile line is at the intersection with the near-surface profile line. These observations suggest that SD SiO2-α+βSiC promotes a different distribution of phases and the catalyst particle. These arrangements of SD SiO2-α+βSiC and SD SiO2-βSiC catalysts are further confirmed with the Raman mapping of the cross-sectional planes at 782 cm−1, corresponding to the cristobalite (Fig. S3). The EDX profiles of Na and Mn are similar in SD SiO2-βSiC, indicating a more uniform radial phase distribution. In contrast, Mn and W profiles (see also Fig. S4) of SD SiO2-α+βSiC show the migration of Mn and W to the surface, with mobile Na present in both surface and bulk to facilitate SiO2 transition. The reason for the enhancement of OCM activity of SD SiO2-α+βSiC can be assigned to the higher exposure of active phases on the surface combined with the SiC phase that is conveniently located at the center of the particle that can effectively equalize and normalize the particle temperature during the high exothermic reaction. This mechanism is mainly missing in poorly thermal conductive cristobalite formed from either amorphous SiO2 or SiC. The cristobalite present on the surface, through its strong peak at 21.7° in SD SiO2-α+βSiC (Fig. 1(b)), can be understood as an indicator of the efficient utilization of Na for the amorphous SiO2-cristobalite transition and the more robust anchoring of W species that could lead to a more prominent presence of Na2WO4 (Palermo et al., 1998). Most SiO2-supported Mn-Na-W catalysts perform better with apparent cristobalite peaks (Yildiz et al., 2014). In the case of SD SiO2-βSiC, the metals are less exposed with more limited cristobalite. These observations highlight the role of SiC properties on the active phase morphology and distribution, which eventually lead to substantially different catalytic performance. The Raman spectra (Fig. S5) and PXRD diffractograms (Fig. S6) of the used catalysts correlate with the observed performance. The TGA of uncalcined samples further confirms the bulk nature of the SiC (Fig. 10 ), where the initial weight loss in both samples at <650°C takes place throughout 3 different regions (<200°C, 200-500°C, and 500-650°C) and could be attributed to the evaporation of water, salt anionic precursors, burn-off of the carbonaceous compounds, and loss of active components in the catalysts. In addition, the weight loss is slightly more significant in the SD SiO2-βSiC sample compared to the SD SiO2-α+βSiC sample, the difference being attributed to the loss of the active phase (Mn-Na-W) in the SD SiO2-βSiC as confirmed from ICP-OES analysis (Table 2). Both catalysts demonstrated a weight gain at temperatures higher than 650°C, which could be attributed to the oxidation of βSiC, which is known to oxidize more easily (Hoffmann et al., 2015). The weight gain in both samples is below the weight gain associated with the stoichiometric conversion of β phase SiC into SiO2, considering the nominal β phase SiC loadings are 30 and 15 wt.% for in SD SiO2-βSiC and SD SiO2-α+βSiC, respectively (the stoichiometric weight increase is 14.96 wt.% and 7.48 wt.%). Therefore, the TGA reaffirms the collective findings of the PXRD, SEM-EDX, and Raman spectroscopy and shows that β phase SiC-containing catalyst is easier to oxidize against the more stable (less oxidation-prone) behavior of the α+β phase SiC counterpart. 3.5 Effect of operating conditions Upon establishing the most suited SiC crystal phase for intraparticle support dilution is α+β, we further explore the performance of SD SiO2-α+βSiC catalyst over a wide range of conditions. Fig. 11 presents the influence of temperature and the CH4/O2 ratio in the feed on the performance of SD SiO2-α+βSiC. The CH4 conversion increases exponentially with temperature in line with Fig. 4 and decreases linearly with CH4/O2, following the behavior described in the literature (Galadima and Muraza, 2016). The discrepancies between the CH4 conversion reported at 800°C in Figs. 6 and 11(a) at similar space-time conditions are due to the different dilution and CH4/O2 ratio in the feed for each case. The most remarkable CH4 conversion (20.1±0.30%) was obtained at the highest temperature and lowest CH4/O2 ratio. The observed values of the O2 conversion are highly affected by both temperature and the CH4/O2 ratio. Higher temperatures inevitably lead to higher O2 conversion due to the enhanced activity, especially at 800°C. The remarkable increase in O2 conversion observed for both catalysts when CH4/O2=5 compared to lower ratios at 700°C is ascribed to the scarce O2 availability in such a case, as the inert dilution in the feed is much higher when CH4/O2=5 than in any other case. The lack of a sudden drop in C2 selectivity associated with the increase in O2 conversion (Fig. 11(b)) highlights the scarcity of O2 in the reaction medium when CH4/O2=5. The C2 selectivity takes similar values at all reaction conditions, remaining almost unaffected by the CH4/O2 ratio in the feed while being linearly dependent on temperature. Despite the increasing C2H4/C2H6 ratio with the decreasing CH4/O2 ratio in the feed, such a dependency is much more limited than the effect of temperature, which increases the C2H4/C2H6 ratio from 0.11±0.00 at 700°C to 1.54±0.01 at 800°C and CH4/O2=3. To further contextualize the results presented in Figure 11, the influence of temperature and the CH4/O2 ratio in the feed on the performance of IMP SiO2 is shown in Fig. S7. 4 Conclusions This work outlines the importance of support composition and blending-shaping methods for direct methane conversion to C2 chemicals through oxidative coupling. In the first set of studies, the spray-drying technique established superiority over other blending-shaping methods in C2 yields. Upon experiments using spray-drying and different SiC crystal phases, α+βSiC was the most active catalyst, whose performance was further improved by using different process parameters. The characterization of the reduced catalysts shows that both the blending-shaping method and SiC crystal phase induce different oxidation behavior in the active phase. These results underline the importance of SiC inclusion in the support. The crystal structure of SiC was observed to play a crucial role in offering high C2 yields, specifically when α+βSiC was used as co-support. The enhancement of the activity of the spray-dried catalyst with α+βSiC can be assigned to the higher exposure of active phases and the different oxidation behavior (higher tendency to oxidation) compared to the catalyst with only βSiC. The further assessment of the process parameters highlighted the existing activity-selectivity trade-off of feeding O2 and CH4, as the latter is required to generate methyl radicals to make the coupling happen while oxidizing the products therefrom. This work highlights the importance of choosing a favorable SiC crystal phase and the blending-shaping method, resulting in an improved catalyst for OCM. coredata.dc:description: Supported Mn-Na-W on silica is a benchmark catalyst for oxidative coupling of methane due to its appropriate ethylene yields. Here we compare eight catalysts with the same active phase (Mn-Na-W) and variable support composition or particle blending-shaping method to evaluate the effect of the support. First, we explore the different preparation methods (impregnation, ball milling, and spray-drying), concluding that spray-drying leads to a promising selective catalyst. Then, we compare different SiC crystal phases (α+β and β), keeping the same composition and shaping method (spray-drying). The catalyst with α+βSiC crystal phase has significantly more activity than the β one in 30 h reaction runs. Finally, we assess the effect of process conditions to improve the yields (15 % at 800°C) of the most promising catalyst: spray-dried and with α+βSiC. The roles of the blending-shaping method and SiC crystal phase are explained by the induced differences in oxidation behavior and active phase distributions.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of the particle blending-shaping method and silicon carbide crystal phase for Mn-Na-W/SiO2-SiC catalyst in oxidative coupling of methane
